author: James Ducker
title: Blackburn searching for eighth permanent manager in seven years after Owen Coyle departure
text:
Blackburn searching for eighth permanent manager in seven years after Owen Coyle departure Owen Coyle has left Blackburn by mutual consent James Ducker 21 February 2017 • 5:35pm 
B lackburn Rovers are searching for their eighth permanent manager in seven years after Owen Coyle departed the club by mutual consent on Tuesday less than nine months after taking charge at Ewood Park. 
Venky’s, Blackburn’s controversial owners, opted to remove Coyle less than 48 hours after the 2-1 FA Cup fifth round defeat by Manchester United amid growing concern about the club being relegated from the Championship this season. 
Blackburn are second bottom of the Championship, three points adrift of safety, after winning just two of their past 13 league matches and have spent just 17 days this season outside the bottom three. 
Coyle is not thought to have seen eye-to-eye with Paul Senior, Blackburn’s recently appointed director of football and operations, and there was some surprise the Scot was still in charge for the United game amid suggestions that he would depart last week. 
Venky’s aim to make a quick appointment but whether they have a new manager in place for Friday’s trip to fellow relegation strugglers Burton Albion remains to be seen. Blackburn then face three successive home matches against Derby County, Wigan Athletic and Cardiff City. Blackburn suffered FA Cup defeat to Man Utd at the weekend 
D avid Dunn and Damien Johnson, the popular former Blackburn players who run the club’s Under-23 side, could be placed in temporary charge of first team training and possibly for the Burton game if no appointment has made by then. 
In a statement, Blackburn said: “The decision has been taken in order to give the club the best possible chance of climbing to a position of safety in the Championship in the remaining 15 games, which starts with the big trip to Burton Albion on Friday night.” 
Coyle’s appointment last June was never accepted by the majority of Blackburn fans owing to his past association with bitter local rivals but he was operating under difficult circumstances at Ewood Park. Who is the deadliest scorer in Europe? 
B lackburn sold centre-halves Grant Hanley and Shane Duffy to Newcastle and Brighton respectively last summer for a combined fee of £10 million, the latest players to depart in the wide-spreading cost cutting at a club where net debts have spiralled past £100 million. 
Of the 14 players Coyle recruited last summer, only one – Derrick Williams – cost a fee as the manager was forced to bring players in on loan or frees and he also had to contend with an extensive injury list when the sales of key players started to bite. 
Although Blackburn had only lost one league match by more than one goal since August, they conceded too many soft, late goals and endured a dreadful start to the campaign that left them playing a game of catch-up. Despite beating league leaders Newcastle home and away, they lost three successive games 3-2 in December and have won just one of their past six in the league. Follow Telegraph Football
